document.masterDocTitle: Battling the un-dead: the status of the Diptera genus-group names originally proposed in Johann Wilhelm Meigen’s 1800 pamphlet

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Battling the un-dead: the status of the Diptera genus-group names originally proposed in Johann Wilhelm Meigen’s 1800 pamphlet

subSubSection.paragraph:
CURRENT STATUS: Unavailable name; work suppressed for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]); treated under
Xylota Meigen, 1822
[ teste Sabrosky (1999: 325) ].

FIRST INCLUDED SPECIES:
Xylota abiens Meigen, 1822
(with
Musca semulator Harris, 1776
,
Musca tristor
Harris, 1776
in synonymy);
Xylota caeruleiventris Zetterstedt, 1843
;
Xylota cuprina Coquillett, 1898
;
Xylota curvipes Loew, 1854
(with
Xylota satanica
Bigot, 1884
in synonymy);
Xylota eumera Loew, 1869
;
Musca femorata Linnaeus, 1758
(with
Syrphus volvulus
Fabricius, 1805
in synonymy);
Scaeva florum Fabricius, 1805
(with
Syrphus lugens Rossi, 1790
,
Xylota nemorum Meigen, 1822
in synonymy);
Xylota fulviventris Bigot, 1861
;
Syrphus ignava Panzer, 1798
;
Xylota lenta Meigen, 1822
(with
Syrphus pigra
Panzer, 1798
in synonymy);
Xylota longa Coquillett, 1898
;
Milesia nemorum Fabricius, 1805
(with
Xylota bifasciata Meigen, 1822
in synonymy);
Xylota nigripes Zetterstedt, 1838
;
Xylota nitida Portschinsky, 1880
;
Xylota pictipes Loew, 1871
;
Syrphus pigra Fabricius, 1794
(with
Xylota crassipes Wahlberg, 1838
,
Milesia haematodes Fabricius, 1805
,
Xylota nigra Walker, 1849
,
Xylota pini
Perris, 1871
in synonymy);
Xylota rufipes Loew, 1873
;
Musca segnis Linnaeus, 1758
[with
Musca brassicaria Fabricius, 1775
(as “
brassicaria Donov.
”) in synonymy],
Musca fucata
Harris, 1776
in synonymy);
Xylota sibirica Loew, 1871
;
Musca silvarum Linnaeus, 1758
(with
Syrphus impigra Rossi, 1790
,
Musca longisco
Harris, 1776
in synonymy);
Xylota tarda Meigen, 1822
(with
Xylota confinis Zetterstedt, 1843
, “
Xylota confluens Apetz et Wahlbg.
in litt. ap. Zett.” in synonymy);
Xylota triangularis Zetterstedt, 1838
(in Bezzi & Stein 1907: 127–132 ).

TYPE SPECIES:
Musca segnis Linnaeus, 1758
, by subsequent designation ( Coquillett 1910a: 621 ).

CURRENT STATUS: Preoccupied by
Zelima Fabricius, 1807
; junior synonym of
Xylota Meigen, 1822
. New Synonymy .

REMARKS:
Zelima
was originally proposed by Meigen (1800: 22) without included species and later made unavailable by the suppression of the entire work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of the I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hendel (1903: 58) proposed
Zelima
in synonymy by treating it as a synonym of
Xylota Meigen, 1803
, but did not include any species. Bezzi & Stein (1907: 127) treated
Zelima
as a synonym of
Xylota Meigen, 1803
, and included 25 species (under
Xylota
). Hendel (1908: 58) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) and to treat
Zelima
as valid, which makes the name available from Hendel (1903) . Coquillett (1910a: 621) selected
Musca segnis Linnaeus, 1758
, which is the type species by subsequent designation.
Musca segnis Linnaeus, 1758
is currently treated in
Xylota Meigen, 1822
[ teste Sabrosky (1999: 325) ], which makes
Zelima Hendel, 1903 a
junior synonym of
Xylota Meigen, 1822
, n. syn .
